title: Probabilities Without Models
summary:
Key ideas
- Some argue that probability shouldn’t be used without a well-defined model
- The above argument does not hold up in situations where important decisions have to be made without a model
- In real-life, even without a model, decision-makers make probability judgments
- Choosing not to make a choice is also a choice with consequences

Key learnings
- Probability judgments without models are necessary in real-life situations
- Refusing to make probability judgments could lead to consequences just the same as making a choice
- Frame choices in terms of probability to check for overconfidence when making decisions

Key questions
- How can we make probability judgments without a model?
- When should we take risks on low probability outcomes?
- How accurate are probability judgments when made without a model?
